channel.title: String colors

item.title: String colors
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Omer_, post:8, topic:444132”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=546447.msg4013071#msg4013071 date=1339386991]

and all OSs that run Java are either UNIX flavours or windows?

yes?..
[/quote]all popular desktop OSes that run Java are either unices (+clones) or windows, however things like jnode exist (which is an almost entirely Java-written OS which doesn’t label itself as a UNIX or anything)

edit: also they should label that library as not just working with UNIX terminals but any ANSI colour-code compliant terminal

JNode development has been inactive for a while now and will probably go defunct soon.[/quote]unfortunately, it was a cool project

Read full topic

[/quote]

yes?..[/quote]all popular desktop OSes that run Java are either unices (+clones) or windows, however things like jnode exist (which is an almost entirely Java-written OS which doesn’t label itself as a UNIX or anything)

edit: also they should label that library as not just working with UNIX terminals but any ANSI colour-code compliant terminal

item.title: String colors
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“s1gma, post:7, topic:443769”][quote author=Alec_ link=topic=546447.msg4012847#msg4012847 date=1339368228]

Using standard Java there isn’t and I doubt there’s any kind of library that would support it over every OS/IDE.

http://www.diogonunes.com/it/work/jcdp/

Print colored messages on a UNIX terminal or a WINDOWS command console.

[/quote]and all OSs that run Java are either UNIX flavours or windows?[/quote]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(software_platform)

Windows, Solaris, Linux, Mac OS X

item.title: String colors
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[quote=“Omer_, post:1, topic:444132”]With the err output stream in the System class, you can output “red text” (although you most likely shouldn’t do this just because you want red text)
Any other colors aren’t supported for all I know and you’d need to use JNI for any attempts.[/quote]

I thought that only happened in IDE consoles.

Read full topic

item.title: String colors
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“ravekitty, post:3, topic:443769”][quote author=Ollie123 link=topic=546447.msg4005980#msg4005980 date=1338649286]
If you mean formatting text for the console, I’m not sure that it’s possible with java. I know for unix you can use control codes, but for windows you’d probably have to use JNI or something. If you must have coloured output, consider using a JTextPane.
[/quote]
What is jtextpane >_<
And do you by any chance, know how to create a simple gui interface?[/quote]
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/components/toplevel.html

Read full topic

@ravekitty wrote:

Ollie123:

If you mean formatting text for the console, I’m not sure that it’s possible with java. I know for unix you can use control codes, but for windows you’d probably have to use JNI or something. If you must have coloured output, consider using a JTextPane.

What is jtextpane >_<
And do you by any chance, know how to create a simple gui interface?

item.title: String colors
item.dc:creator: @ravekitty ravekitty
item.description:
@ravekitty wrote:

Once again, sorry for spamming this thread.
Is it possible to create a color for a string like this


				System.out.println("You have been asked 20 questions!");

If so, could you give me an example?

Read full topic
